thread.title: 'Tag a mate who loves pineapple on their pizza': how Australian police bought into meme culture
thread.title_full: 'Tag a mate who loves pineapple on their pizza': how Australian police bought into meme culture

author: Elle Hunt
title: 'Tag a mate who loves pineapple on their pizza': how Australian police bought into meme culture
text:
March 14, 2017 
The force has been active on social media for the best part of a decade, but Strath Gordon, its director of public affairs, confirms that what he calls the â€œmeme strategyâ€ has been deployed only in the past two months. 
Last week alone, the page amassed more than 13,000 new likes, overtaking the Bureau of Meteorology on the leaderboard of Australian government organisations. 
More exciting to Gordon is the rise in the number of comments and shares: NSW Police now has the highest engagement of any Australian government organisation on Facebook, he says, with no small amount of pride. The invitation to â€œtag a mate who loves pineapple ğŸ on their pizza ğŸ•â€ drew the best part of 7,000 comments and nearly 3,000 shares. 
Itâ€™s no secret direct appeals and humour are effective at raising responses on social media, and memes of the sort now being posted by NSW Police are not especially unusual, even among government organisations. â€œDank memesâ€ were the currency of last yearâ€™s federal election campaign for political parties and lobby groups alike. Memes to an end: how the internet Photoshopped the Australian election Read more 
But they seem somehow more incongruous coming from Australiaâ€™s oldest and largest police organisation, with the stated aim of â€œpreventing, detecting and investigating crimeâ€ and â€œmaintaining social orderâ€. 
Gordon points out NSW is not the first police force, in Australia or the world, to â€œdelve into the humourâ€, and says there is â€œhealthy competitionâ€ between jurisdictions â€“ singling out Queensland â€“ for social media wins. 
The admittedly slight strain of opposition to NSW Policeâ€™s new online brand has centred on whether it is appropriate for the police to have a public presence akin to that of, say, Dennyâ€™s â€“ a US fast-food restaurant now better known for its outsider social media presence than its pancakes. 
Writer Alex McKinnon shared the â€œtag a mate who loves pineappleâ€ post on his own Facebook page with the comment: â€œWould prefer for NSW Police Force to target systemic bias in their own ranks, excessive use of force and over-policing of minorities but that probably wouldnâ€™t be as ~~~shareable~~~â€. Cops are funny on social media. But should they ever be seen as "one of us"? | Courtney Robinson Read more 
Gordon denies the forceâ€™s Facebook presence is making light of the serious business of policing. He admits â€œthere have been examplesâ€ of posts being misjudged (he hints at a social campaign by the New York police department that backfired spectacularly in 2014 ) but not by NSW (â€œthough obviously Iâ€™m not going to be rushing to tell youâ€). 
â€œWe understand that tone, we understand that thereâ€™s a fine line, and you always have to be a little cautious,â€ he says. â€œI think weâ€™ve got the balance about right. ... Nothingâ€™s been regarded as crossing the line and people are usually pretty quick to tell us. 
â€œWe also have to accept that some people donâ€™t agree with the police forceâ€™s approach to certain things. People on one side of the equation might be cheering it on, and others might be less than happy.â€ 
Regardless of appropriateness, at face value there is certainly a very thin blue line between policing and preferences for pineapple on pizza. Some people might say â€˜why arenâ€™t you out catching crooks instead of being funnyâ€™ Strath Gordon 
â€œPeople donâ€™t associate the memes with what weâ€™re trying to achieve,â€ Gordon agrees. raen ğŸŒ¹ (@pIuto) did the nsw police page really just say nek minnit that meme is from like 2011 omg i can't believe this https://t.co/wmTwHHnS2p March 7, 2017 
But they serve a dual purpose, he says, the first being that they show â€œthe police force do have a sense of humourâ€. The second is strategic: high levels of engagement on some posts train Facebookâ€™s notoriously opaque algorithm to prioritise all of them. 
Gordon says the forceâ€™s surveys of its Facebook followers suggest they see it as a trusted source of information and want to see more from it on social media, not less. 
â€œAnd we know that if your engagement falls away, the chances of your followers receiving your posts reduces significantly.â€ 
The forceâ€™s page has many more posts about developing incidents, as well as warnings and appeals for help, than the selection that appear on followersâ€™ timelines probably indicates. The response raised by jokes about Adele and Justin Bieber paves the way for its other more conventional posts, Gordon says. 
â€œThe purpose of the meme is to enhance communication â€“ theyâ€™re a means to an end, theyâ€™re not an end in themselves ... I understand that in the social media context, some people might say â€˜why arenâ€™t you out catching crooks instead of being funnyâ€™. 
â€œBut in fact itâ€™s a very deliberate strategy, itâ€™s a very legitimate thing for us to be doing.â€ 
The memes have also helped the police connect with a new demographic. â€œWe know, just anecdotally, that young people are enjoying that stuff because theyâ€™re not really expecting it to come from the cops,â€ Gordon says. 
It is certainly difficult to imagine discussion of the Atlanta rap trio Migos and the â€œrain drop/drop topâ€ meme they inspired at the police HQ in Parramatta. As with any display of digital literacy by an unexpected source (viz Hillary Clinton dabbing on Ellen), discussion of the forceâ€™s new strategy has been framed in terms of who is to blame. ashleightui (@ashleightui) March 14, 2017 
The forceâ€™s social media team consists of two people, Gordon says, and â€œmost of those amusing memes are dreamed up by one of themâ€. 
Dejan Stojadinovic, 26, demurs at this description, saying itâ€™s a â€œteam effortâ€. He has worked at NSW Police for about four years and now holds the title of digital media officer. 
He says he draws inspiration for viral trends to â€œappropriate ... and tie [into] our corporate messagingâ€ from his own Facebook timeline, and the response has been â€œoverwhelmingly positiveâ€. 
â€œI think on a personal level Iâ€™m pretty obsessed with everything popular culture, and I always keep a close eye, even in my own time, on meme pages and blogs.â€ 
His current favourite is â€œHow Italians Do Things?â€ â€“ documented only three days ago by the ever-expanding website KnowYourMeme. (By Monday, it had appeared on the NSW Police page, raising more than 2,600 likes in an hour.) 
â€œI donâ€™t really get why itâ€™s so popular, but I actually find that one quite funny,â€ Stojadinovic says. â€œBut you know â€“ every day I see one that makes me chuckle a little bit.â€ Topics
